In this work, a series of LaMnO3 (LM) perovskite catalysts modified at A and B sites were prepared to accelerate soot combustion. The La0.68Sr0.2K0.12Mn0.9Cu0.1O3-δ (LSK0.12MCu0.1) modified by Sr, K and Cu has good catalytic activity and cycle stability, the presence of NO can obviously promote the oxidation of soot. A variety of characterization results show that doping the A and B sites of perovskite will not destroy the original structure of perovskite, and the doped ions (Sr2+, K+, and Cu2+) can enter the perovskite catalyst well, which may be conducive to the formation of more oxygen defects and active oxygen species. According to the DFT calculation, adding Sr and K to the A sites can alter how atoms interact in a perovskite catalyst, increase the amount of unsaturated coordination bonds, and encourage the development of high-valence active ions (Mn4+) and oxygen defects. The doping of transition metal to the B sites results in the formation of the Cu-O-Mn link, which forms the Mn(Cu)O6 octahedron and stimulates the development of oxygen vacancies and the release of active oxygen. This study will provide an important reference for developing non-precious metal-based perovskite materials with high activity and low cost for catalytic combustion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Soot combustion Potassium supported Active oxygen DFT calculation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Diesel vehicles have a steady increase popular in transportation owing to their strong power, good durability, stable operation, and high thermal efficiency [1,2]. However, the pollutants emitted by diesel vehicles, including nitrogen oxides (NO x ), carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons (HC), as well as soot particles, pose serious harm to environmental and human health [3,4]. In particular, soot particles from diesel exhaust are one of the major contributions of air pollution, which can induce bronchitis and lung cancers diseases [5,6]. DPF is a very efficient device that can be used to filter and eliminate soot [7]. The removal of soot captured by DPF can make it regenerate and play a role again. The regeneration of DPF includes active regeneration and passive regeneration. The former means that the DPF is heated regularly to eliminate the accumulated soot. DPF can play a corresponding role again. The latter reduces the combustion temperature of soot by selecting suitable catalysts to assist the oxidation process of soot. The soot accumulated on the DPF is removed in the diesel exhaust temperature range (150–400 °C). The combination of catalyst and DPF is considered to be the most effective application method [8]. While the removal efficiency of soot depends largely on the performance of the catalysts. The synthesis of catalysts with good redox activity is considered to be the most critical step in promoting soot oxidation. In general, noble metal catalysts outperform non-precious metal catalysts in terms of effectiveness, which can significantly improve the capacity of soot purification and make them essential active components in commercial catalysts. However, the former is significantly more expensive and scarce than the latter [9]. As a result, there is more interest in creating non-precious metals that are both affordable and efficient at removing soot. According to the active components of the catalyst, the soot combustion catalysts can be divided into noble metals [10–12], alkali metal oxides [13–16], transition oxides [17–21] and perovskite-type oxides [22,23]. Among these catalysts, ABO3 type of perovskite have been considered as a research hotspot in soot combustion owing to their low cost, thermal stability and structural stability than the single oxides [24–27]. However, the reactivity of LaMnO3 catalyst alone in catalytic oxidation is always unsatisfactory. In order to further improve the intrinsic activity of this perovskite-type material, it will be an effective method to modify perovskite-type composites by doping A or B sites. When the A-site cations are replaced by low-valent alkali metals or alkaline earth metals, the B-site cations will undergo a transformation to a higher oxidation state to preserve the electrical neutrality, which will facilitate the development of oxygen vacancies. The number of crystal defects and the content of oxygen vacancies increases when the B position cations are partially replaced [28–30]. Tran et al. [31] doped and modified LaAlO3 perovskite with Co, and explored the effect of NO x -assisted on soot oxidation performance. The results showed that doping Co would lead to the distortion of BO6 octahedron, which caused the lattice distortion of perovskite, enhanced the migration and transformation of lattice oxygen, and then improved the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Calvo et al. [32] employed Sr2+ ions to partially replace La3+ in La-Mn perovskite to create a variety of catalysts. They discovered that Sr2+-doped catalysts may swiftly convert from NO to NO2. This is connected to the Sr induced valence imbalance in the La-Mn perovskite system, which leads to the system producing more high-valence active ions and oxygen vacancies. The activity of Sr-doped La-Co catalysts with porous nanostructures was found to be superior to that of other catalysts by the researchers after they investigated the auxiliary impact of various types on soot reduction at low operating temperatures of perovskite catalysts [33,34]. Furthermore, in addition to single-element doping of perovskite, it is possible to dope A- site or B-site with two elements. In lanthanum manganate perovskite system, partial substitution and doping of A and B elements with alkali metal (K) or transition metal (Cu) can improve the active oxygen density and redox ability of catalyst materials, and can oxidize soot particles at lower temperature [35]. In particular for catalytic oxidation, various metal species have distinct impacts on the activity in the conjunction of perovskite structure. Zhao et al. [36] explored the effect of low-valent K, Sr and Pr on the oxidation performance of soot after replacing La in LaMnO3. It is found that the presence of K+ weakens Mn-O, leading to the formation of high-valence Mn and reactive oxygen species, which significantly improves the rate of catalytic reaction. The catalytic activity of these catalysts for soot follows the order of La0.8K0.2MnO3 > La0.7K0.3MnO3 > La0.9K0.1MnO3 > La0.9Sr0.1MnO3 > La0.9Pr0.1MnO3 > LaMnO3. Díaz et al. [37] designed a series of K and Ni doped lanthanum cobaltate perovskites. It was found that the doping of K and Ni changed the structure and physical and chemical properties of the catalyst, and affected the distribution of active centers such as oxygen vacancies (α-O /Olatt) and active substances (Co3+ / Co2+). Compared with the original lanthanum cobaltate, the activity of the catalyst was significantly improved. It is possible to create effective redox catalysts by replacing the cations at the A or B sites of perovskites. Nevertheless, the primary focus of the current research is on the variation in activity of perovskite cations both before and after substitution [38,39]. Theoretical study on the cationic replacement of perovskite A and B sites is insufficiently systematic, and research on soot removal by the substituted catalyst is similarly insufficient [40,41]. In this work, we use highly active K+ and highly electronegative transition metal (Cu) to modify LaMnO3-based perovskite to obtain catalytic materials with high activity and high stability for catalytic oxidation. A series of LaMnO3 perovskite catalysts, such as A and B sites double-doped La0.8- x Sr0.2K x Mn1-yCuyO3-δ (x = 0, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.10, 0.12, 0.15, y = 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, LSK x MCu y ), were synthesized using the citric acid complexation approach. It is used to catalyze soot combustion at low temperatures in the absence of precious metals. The bonding properties and catalytic activity of K/Cu doped perovskite oxides were studied by density functional theory (DFT). Combined with a series of characterization methods, the effect of the structure of the catalyst on the catalytic soot activity was studied, and the essential characteristics of the activity enhancement caused by A/B site doping and the active oxygen species in the reaction were discussed. This provides a reference for the modification of ABO3-type perovskite by A and B ions to design efficient and stable non-precious metal catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation A series of LaMnO3 based perovskites were prepared by sol-gel method [42].The synthesized LaMnO3, La0.8Sr0.2MnO3, La0.8- x Sr0.2K x MnO3 (x = 0, 0.02, 0.06, 0.10, 0.12, 0.15), La0.68Sr0.2K0.12Mn1- y CuyO3 (y = 0.05, 0.1 and 0.15) and La0.68Sr0.2K0.12Mn0.9M0.1O3 (LSK0.12MB0.1, B=Co, Ni) powders were named LM, LSM, LSK x M, LSK0.12MCuy, LSK0.12MCo0.1, LSK0.12MNi0.1. The details of the preparation can be seen in the support information. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Analytical methods including XRD, FT-IR, TEM, SEM, XPS, H2-TPR, and others were used to describe the essential physicochemical characteristics of catalysts. The supporting materials provides specific experimental protocols. 2.3 Measurements of catalytic oxidation activity Through the use of soot-temperature programmed oxidation (Soot-TPO), which quantitatively analyses the temperature at 10 %, 50 %, and 90 % soot conversion, respectively, catalytic activity was assessed. It should be pointed out that tight contact mode was chosen to conduct these tests since it maximizes the contact between catalyst and soot [43,44]. The detailed manipulation and calculation were shown in the Supporting Information. 2.4 DFT calculations To determine the energy of a system of materials ground state, the electron density of the system is computed using density functional theory (DFT). The partial density of states (PDOS) may be used to analyze the contribution of the electronic states based on their directional momentum. The orbital overlap between the catalyst its constituent parts may be calculated using PDOS, and the strength of the bonds between the atoms can be evaluated. The crystal structure that was employed in the calculation is depicted in Fig. 1 , and the supporting information contains the calculation specifics. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Results of catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis As shown in Fig. 2 , the characteristic peaks of the catalyst at 22.91°, 32.45°, 40.11°, 46.84° and 58.10° correspond to (012), (110), (202), (024) and (214) crystals of LaMnO3 standard card (PDF#88-0127), respectively. This shows that the catalyst was prepared to produce a rhomboidal phase perovskite when Sr and K co-substituted the A site in LaMnO3. Additionally, there were no extra diffraction peaks of doped metal compounds were seen, indicating that the catalyst had successfully formed its distinctive perovskite peaks. This phenomenon indicates that the co-doping of Sr and K did not destroy the perovskite structure and was doped into the fixed structure of the perovskite oxide. When transition metals are used to dope the B site, the diffraction peaks of perovskite are all shifted to high angles (Fig. 2b), which may be related to the doping of transition metals into the perovskite lattice. However, the variation trends of the diffraction peak angles are different when different Cu doping amounts are used. When the doping amount is less, the diffraction peak angle shifts to the right, which may be related to the existence of Cu2+ in the perovskite lattice. Since the ionic radius of Cu2+ (0.73 Å) is larger than that of Mn3+ (0.65 Å) and Mn4+ (0.53 Å), the substitution of Cu should lead to the expansion rather than contraction of the crystal plane [45,46]. The reason for this phenomenon may be that the doping of low valence Cu2+ leads to obvious oxidation, which makes the charge neutral Mn3+ transform to Mn4+ [32,47]. 3.1.2 Infrared analysis The catalysts were examined by FT-IR spectroscopy in order to learn more about the component of the phases of the catalysts. It can be seen from the Fig. 3 that all samples have absorption peaks at 415 cm−1 and 620 cm−1. The initial peak among them is a result of the Mn–O bonds flexion vibration, whereas the latter peak is a result of the distinctive peak of the perovskite structure stretching vibration [35,48,49]. These results further demonstrate that the samples all have a similar perovskite structure. The samples peak at 620 cm−1 widened and lost strength when the A site was substituted. This phenomenon is because when low-valent Sr2+ and K+ replace high-valent La3+, part of Mn3+ loses electrons and transforms into Mn4+ to maintain the electrical neutrality of the catalyst system. The lengths of the three pairs of Mn–O bonds are comparable and MnO6 tends to form a regular octahedron. This causes the vibration to diminish, lowering the strength of the absorption peak. Additionally, the peak of the B site when Cu2+ is substituted is greater than that of other samples, indicating that the replacement of Cu may maintain the perovskites structural integrity. These results appear to concur with the XRD outcomes. 3.1.3 SEM analysis To examine the microscopic form of samples that had been prepared at various resolutions, SEM was employed to describe them. The LM catalyst has a columnar molecular structure (Fig. 4 a and b). A flocculent porous structure is visible on the surface of the catalyst when the A site is initially doped with Sr (Fig. 4c and d), which indicated that the morphology of catalyst has been changed. The surface of catalyst particle size altered after being doped with K, exhibiting a process known as porous amalgamation that was brought on by the disparity in radii between La3+ and K+ [7]. After doping B sites and Cu ions, the morphology of the catalyst shows a honeycomb porous structure, and its particle size is also significantly reduced, indicating that the addition of Cu will have a certain effect on the morphology of the catalyst. In addition, the elemental distribution of LSK0.12MCu0.1 was studied by Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the distribution of each element is relatively uniform, which further confirms that the ions at A and B positions have been successfully replaced. 3.1.4 TEM analysis The produced catalyst was analyzed by TEM as shown in Fig. 6 . All of the catalysts that have been synthesized are made up of crystalline particles, which is consistent with the experimental SEM findings. HR-TEM was used to study the exposed crystal planes of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6b, the visible lattice distance of LM is 0.23 nm, which is equivalent to the (113) lattice plane of the standard PDF card (PDF # 88-0127). The catalysts doped at the A and B sites were found to have lattice spacing of 0.38 nm and 0.27 nm, respectively, which correlates to the (012) and (104) crystal planes of LaMnO3. These outcomes concur with the XRD. 3.1.5 Specific surface area and pore size analysis The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of LM-based perovskite catalysts were determined and the results are shown in Fig. 7 a. The specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst are summarized in Table 1 . The prepared catalysts exhibit a typical type IV adsorption isotherm, which indicates that the adsorbate N2 has strong adsorption on the catalyst surface. In the range of relative pressure (P/ P0) of 0.9–1.0, the hysteresis curve of the catalyst can be classified as H3 type, indicating that there is intergranular aggregation in the catalyst [50,51]. It can be seen from Table 1 that the specific surface area of LM is low, only 6.73 m2 / g. After doping the A site, the specific surface area increases. However, when the B-site is doped with Cu, the specific surface area of the catalyst decreases. The catalyst exhibits a microporous structure (Fig. 7b). This can be due to the fact that a certain level of Cu doping can alter the lattice, causing the grain size to increase and the specific surface area to decrease. 3.1.6 XPS analysis The composition, concentration, and valence state of the catalyst surface components have a significant role in regulating the catalytic performance in the catalytic combustion of soot, which is a heterogeneous reaction process. The findings of XPS measurements on the LM-based perovskite catalyst are displayed in Fig. 8 and were used to investigate the chemical valence states of the Mn and O elements in the catalyst. By calculating the ratio of various elements on the catalyst surface, it is possible to further explain how metal doping changes the chemical valence states of the catalysts (Table 2 ). The Mn 2p3/2 XPS spectrum of the catalyst is fitted as two separate peaks with binding energies located at 641.9 and 644.5 eV, respectively (Fig. 8a). The peak at 641.9 eV is assigned to Mn3+ on the catalyst surface in the literature, whereas the peak at 644.5 eV is attributed to Mn4+ [52,53]. It can be seen from Table 2 that the content of Mn4+ on the surface of LM catalyst is less, about 17.2 %. Compared with LM, the Mn4+ content of the LSM catalyst is slightly increased, which can be attributed to the introduction of Sr that disrupts the balance of valence states in the perovskite, thereby generating Mn4+ to maintain the charge balance. It was discovered that the Mn4+ content of the LSK0.12M catalyst rose significantly after K doping was applied to the A site. This is mostly because K has the ability to weaken the Mn-O link and create an unstable form of Mn3+, which encourages the creation of Mn4+ once more. It was discovered that LSK0.12MCu0.1 had the highest Mn4+ content when the B site was doped with Cu on the basis of this catalyst. It shows that doping an appropriate amount of Cu is beneficial to the formation of Mn4+, which may be traced to the reaction cycle process of Cu2++Mn3+↔Cu++Mn4+, which drives the formation of Mn4+. Previous studies have shown that the presence of Mn4+ leads to charge valence imbalance and promotes the creation of active sites in the LM-based perovskite lattice [54]. The average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn was calculated according to the empirical equation (i.e., AOS=8.956 − 1.126 × ΔE), in which ΔE represents the binding energy difference value between the two peaks of Mn 3s XPS spectra [55–57]. It can be seen from Mn 3s that the ΔE in LSK0.12MCu0.1 is the smallest and its AOS value is the largest (Table 2), which further indicates that its system contains more Mn4+. Fig. 8b shows the O 1s XPS spectrum of the catalysts and O element exists as three different oxygen species on the catalytic surface. The peak at binding energy at 529.2 eV corresponds to lattice oxygen (Olatt, O2−), and the peaks at 531.0 and 532.6 eV are attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads, peroxide species O−, superoxide species O2 −) [58,59]. In soot catalytic oxidation, it is generally believed that Oads is an active oxygen species and actively participates in the oxidation reaction. The oxidation ability of the catalyst is positively correlated with the content of Oads [54,60]. In general, the peak area of Oads is related to the surface oxygen vacancy concentration, and the oxygen vacancy content in the catalyst can be evaluated according to the Oads/Olatt ratio [61–63]. The Oads/Olatt ratios of different catalysts are shown in Table 2 (Olatt=OI, Oads=OII+OIII), and the order is: LSK0.12MCu0.1 (1.52) > LSK0.12MCu0.05 (1.42) > LSK0.12MCu0.15 (1.23) > LSK0.12M (1.16) > LSM (1.01) > LM (0.89). The results show that the absence of oxygen on the catalyst surface may be greatly increased by A and B site doping. This could raise the quantity of adsorbed oxygen there and boost the catalytic surface oxidation capability. Compared with other catalysts, LSK0.12Cu0.1 has more oxygen vacancies, indicating that it has a strong capacity for surface oxidation and is better able to catalyze soot combustion. 3.1.7 H2-TPR analysis The redox ability of the catalyst was evaluated by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 9 , all catalysts exhibited multiple reduction peaks. The two processes that result in the reduction peaks in the low temperature region for LM (LaMnO3) catalysts are the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and the decrease of surface adsorption oxygen. The peak at high temperature (770 °C) is considered to be caused by the corresponding decrease of Mn3+ to Mn2+ [64]. When the A site was doped with Sr and K, the decreased peak shifted to a lower temperature. At the same time, a faint reduction peak emerged about 290 °C, and its size and intensity grew. The reduction ability of the catalyst is greatly affected by the location of the reduction peak and the corresponding size of the peak region. As the temperature decreases, the ability of catalysts to adsorb oxygen rises, as does the size of the reduction peak, which indicates that the catalyst has absorbed more oxygen. Due to the loss of coordination and production of oxygen vacancies in some of the its oxygen, the addition of Sr and K increases the oxygen motility and oxygen adsorption content on the surface of the catalyst [65,66]. Additionally, due to the system electrical neutrality, the replacement of Sr and K for La3+ will result in the creation of additional Mn4+ [67]. Active elements including adsorbed oxygen and Mn4+ contribute to the strong reduction activity of LSM and LSK0.12M. The temperature of the reduction peak lowers initially with Cu2+ doping on the basis of LSK0.12M catalyst, and then rises as a result of Cu2+ doping. The reduction peak of LSK0.12MCuy catalyst is the mixed peak of Cu2+→Cu+, Mn4+→Mn3+ and surface adsorbed oxygen reduction at about 270 °C [68]. The development of the mixing peak indicates that the addition of Cu will weaken the Mn–O bond and increase the amount of Mn4+ and active oxygen on the catalytic surface, improving the reduction efficiency of the catalysts. The reduction peak of LSK0.12MCu0.1 is seen at lower temperatures in all locations when the doping concentration is 0.10, suggesting that LSK0.12Cu0.1 may have the best reduction ability in soot combustion. The moderate reduction peak, which occurs at around 610 °C, is caused by the reduction of lattice oxygen with the conversion of Mn3+ to Mn2+. Surface lattice oxygen can increase the catalytic activity of soot by promoting the production of species of reactive oxygen [4]. 3.2 Catalytic activity for soot combustion The catalytic activity of the catalyst to soot combustion was examined using temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) under both tight and loose contact circumstances. Fig. 10 shows the change of CO2 concentration with temperature when the catalyst and soot are in tight contact. The corresponding soot catalytic combustion performance T10, T50, T90 and S C O 2 value summary in Table S1. It can be clearly seen from Fig. 10 that when the catalyst participates in soot combustion, the combustion temperature of soot is significantly reduced, and the selectivity of CO2 is improved to a certain extent, indicating that the prepared catalyst plays a positive role in catalyzing soot combustion. The LM catalyst has a certain activity, and the T10, T50 and T90 are 373, 418 and 473 °C, respectively. The performance of the catalyst first rises and then diminishes when the A site is doped with various amounts of Sr and K, and the order of T90 activity of each catalyst is as follows: LSK0.12M (420 °C) > LSK0.1 M (422 °C) > LSK0.15M (424 °C) > LSK0.06M (448 °C) > LSK0.02M (455 °C) > LSM (460 °C) > LM (473 °C). This indicates that the doping of Sr and K can improve the catalytic activity of LM perovskite. Among them, the LSK0.12M catalyst showed the best catalytic performance. Fig. 10(c–d) shows that the B-site doped catalysts with better activity of LSK0.12M catalysts using Cu exhibited excellent catalytic activity, especially LSK0.12MCu0.1 with the lowest T90 (399 °C), compared with the catalyst doped with Co and Ni in the same proportion is better. Additionally, TPO tests with loose connections were carried out in both the presence and absence of NO to assess the B=Co and Ni; the outcomes are displayed in Fig. 11 and Table S2. It can be seen from Fig. 11 revealed all catalysts activities exhibited the same pattern under tight and loose contact conditions. It is important to note that all catalysts T10, T50, and T90 values are further decreased when a little quantity of NO is added to the reaction atmosphere in comparison to an O2 atmospheric. The main reason for this is that the presence of NO encourages the production of NO2, which is necessary to carry out the soot oxidation process. It efficiently encourages the catalytic combustion of soot at low temperatures since NO2 has a larger oxidation capacity than O2 [69]. As can be observed from Table S2, LSK0.12MCu0.1, with a T90 of 420 °C, displayed the best oxidation activity of all the produced catalysts. The findings of the aforementioned catalytic activity further attest to the fact that the right metal doping on the A and B sites can successfully enable the enhancement of the catalytic efficiency. The stability assessment of catalysts for soot burning was done while taking the complexity of diesel exhaust components into consideration. The change of T90 and S C O 2 of LSK0.12MCu0.1 after four TPO cycle tests in close contact to evaluate the endurance of the catalyst (Fig. S1). The experimental results showed that after four cycles, the T90 value of LSK0.12MCu0.1 increased slightly, and the CO2 selectivity was still above 95 %. This indicates that LSK0.12MCu0.1 can be reused in the catalytic oxidation of soot, and its catalytic activity remains good. As shown in Table S3, the catalytic activity of LSK0.12MCu0.1 still has good advantages compared with the catalysts reported in other literatures. In addition to the catalytic oxidation of simulated soot by the above research catalyst, the soot removal efficiency of LSK0.12MCu0.1 on vehicle emissions was also investigated under real conditions. As shown in Fig. S2 and Table S4, under the same experimental conditions, compared with the experimental results of the model soot, the T90 of the real soot is higher, which may be explained by the intricacy of the components of the real soot. When the catalyst was mixed with real soot, compared with the experimental data of catalytic model soot, T10, T50 and T90 did not change significantly, indicating that the LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity and has certain application prospects. In addition, the thermal stability of LSK0.12M and LSK0.12MCu0.1 at 700 °C for 20 h was compared. The activity indexes of the catalyst after heat treatment for soot oxidation are shown in Fig.S3 and Table S5. After long-term heat treatment and aging, the activity of LSK0.12M and LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst decreased, and the T90 and T50 values of the catalyst for soot oxidation increased compared with the fresh catalyst. That is to say, the catalytic activity of the catalyst will decrease at high temperature. But the activity of the LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst decreased less than that of the LSM catalyst. It shows that doping Cu will make the catalyst have a certain resistance to sintering to a certain extent 3.3 Catalyst DOS analysis Fig. 12 show the PDOS diagrams of LM, LSM, LSK0.12M and LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst. It can be observed that the valence band of −40 eV to −30 eV has a very steep peak in the La s orbitals of the four catalysts. The absence of any apparent peaks from other atoms in this range suggests that no atoms have contact to create chemical bonds in this energy range. In the −30 eV to −10 eV valence band, the s orbital of the O atom and the p orbital of the La atom in the four perovskite catalysts displayed clear and sharp peaks, whereas the characteristic orbitals (s, p, and d) of Mn showed weak characteristic peaks. This shows that the catalyst system in this range is predominantly produced by the interaction of the electrons of La and O to form chemical bonds, with assistance from the interaction of the electrons of Mn and O. There is little delocalization between these electrons, little orbital overlap, little electron hybridization, and little binding force. In this low energy area, the interactions between O, La, and Sr, K, O, Mn, and Cu, as well as the stability of the catalysts overall structure, are all insufficient. In the valence band of −10 eV to 0 eV, the p orbitals of O atoms overlap with the d orbitals of Mn atoms, providing an obvious resonance. This is mainly caused by the interaction between the 3d orbital electrons of Mn and the 2p orbital electrons of O. It is obvious that O 2p and Mn 3d electrons are the main generators of the chemical bonds in the catalytic system, with similar contributions from O 2p, Mn s and p orbital electrons. The orbital electrons between Mn and O hybridize to create a stable MnO6 octahedral structure, which promotes the general stability of perovskite catalysts and upholds the stability of the whole catalytic system [70,71]. The p orbital peak of O, the d orbital peak of Mn, and the d orbital peak of La in the catalyst system clearly overlap in the valence band between 0 eV and 10 eV, which indicating interaction between the electrons of the three elements. However, there is a greater connection between the p orbitals of O and the d orbitals of Mn than there is between the p orbitals of O and the d orbitals of La. This shows that the d-orbital electron of the Mn atom is changed through the site of Sr2+ and K+ doped La3+, and the performance of the LM perovskite catalyst is improved. The main reason is that after the perovskite structure is doped with Sr and K ions, the charge in the system becomes non-conservation and many unsaturated coordination bonds are formed. To keep the system stable and preserve electrical neutrality, the d orbital electrons of Mn must be changed. The process of this change will enhance the activity of perovskite catalysts. As shown by Fig. 12b, it can be found that at the bottom of the conduction band (0 eV ∼ 10 eV) of the catalyst, the peak overlap of the d orbital of La and the p orbital of O becomes smaller. This occurs as a result of Sr replacing the A site in LM, which reduces the strength of La d orbital peak and the degree of atom-to-atom electron hybridization, as well as turn reduce the interaction between O and La in the LSM perovskite system. Therefore, a portion of the O in the lattice does not coordinate with La and forms an oxygen defect unit cell, which improves the oxidation ability of the LSM catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 12c that doping K in LSM weakens the intensity of the s orbital peak of O in the valence band from −30 eV to −10 eV, and appears to be a sharp peak. The s electron delocalization of O is weak and the bonding ability is decreased. The p orbital distribution of La changes, the interaction between O and Sr, O and La is weakened, and the bonding ability is low, which makes it easy to form an oxygen defect unit cell. In addition, due to the doping of K, the p-orbital distribution of O is changed, the local peak is also changed, and the p-electron delocalization of O is weakened in the valence band of −10 eV ∼ 0 eV. The Mn–O bond becomes weaker, the Mn-O peak intensity and overlap diminish, and the lattice oxygen in the system is readily impacted to migrate, which causes the production of oxygen defect cells and oxygen vacancies in the system. In Fig. 12d, it is evident that the interaction between the d orbitals of Mn, the p orbitals of O, and the d orbitals of Cu is the key factor in the formation of chemical bonds at the bottom of the conduction band of the LSK0.12MCu0.1 perovskite catalyst (0 eV-10 eV). Among them, the existence of Cu and Mn is the main factor affecting the chemical characteristics of the catalyst system. In comparison to the LSK0.12M catalyst, the doping of Cu increases the electron delocalization, decreases the local peak, diminishes the intensity of O, and strengthens the bonding with Cu. It also increases the p-orbital range of O. Close to the 0 eV valence band, the p orbitals of O overlap with the d orbitals of Mn and Cu, respectively. Mn–O and Cu–O bonds are created as a result of this interaction between Mn, O, and Cu in the octahedral structure of the catalyst system, ensuring the stability of the catalytic system. In conclusion, adding Sr, K, and Cu to LM perovskite can alter the way that atoms interact with one another in the system, making it simple to produce oxygen defect unit cells that will boost the catalyst's intrinsic activity and oxidation capacity. 3.4 Discussion The interaction between metals will affect the performance of the catalyst. The experiments demonstrated that the La0.8- x Sr0.2K x Mn1- y B y O3-δ (L0.8-xSK x MCu y ) composite perovskite catalyst had superior catalytic activity than the LM. The catalytic activity of perovskite was altered by the addition of Sr, K, and Cu. Among the samples, LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst has the strongest oxidation ability to soot and shows good stability. This has to do with how the introduction of the ions of transition metals to the A and B sites changed the catalysts physicochemical makeup and structural composition. The specific surface area of the LM perovskite catalyst will vary if the A site is modified with an alkali metal or an alkaline earth metal, and the catalyst's structure and morphology will change if the B site is modified with a transition metal (Fig. 4 and Table 1). The specific surface area of LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst modified at A and B sites is higher than that of LM perovskite catalysts, and the change of specific surface area is more favorable for the exposure of surface-active sites of catalysts. The special physical and chemical properties of the catalyst is the internal driving force of whether it can show excellent performance [72]. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that when alkaline earth metals or alkali metals (Sr and K) are doped to modify the A site of LM, a unique perovskite characteristic peak is formed. It shows that the doping of Sr and K maintains the stability of perovskite system. In consequence of the lattice expansion caused by the solid solution of Cu2+, the location of the characteristic peak changes when transition metal (Cu) is introduced to the LM perovskite. As Cu2+ concentration rises, it joins forces with the nearby Mn to create a Cu-O-Mn link (Figs. 2 and 3). This demonstrates that the interaction between atoms in the system will alter as a result of the doping modification of LM A and B. As additional Cu–O–Mn bonds, unsaturated coordination ions, and oxygen defects (oxygen vacancies) occur in the crystal cell, the doping of Cu to partially replace the Mn site has become an essential aspect of the system. A crucial component of the system is the doping of Cu to partially replace the Mn site as more Cu–O–Mn bonds, unsaturated coordination ions, and oxygen defects (oxygen vacancies) appear in the crystal cell, making the oxygen in the lattice system dissociate more readily and form vacancies. Reactive oxygen compounds (O*), a type of oxygen, are created when there are vacancies because they absorb gaseous oxygen. In the La0.8-xSr0.2KxMn1-yByO3 perovskite catalysts, O* was assumed to play an essential part in catalytic combustion and is present in different amounts together with active materials (Mn4+). The LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst has the largest relative proportion of active ingredients and the best soot oxidation activity. The results from the experiments of XPS and H2-TPR also showed that LSK0.12MCu0.1 had a higher surface-active oxygen content than other types of catalysts, which was consistent with the findings of catalytic activity. A reaction path for LSK0.12MCu0.1 catalyst to remove soot was proposed, as shown in Scheme 1 . The catalytic activity of perovskite (ABO3) catalysts is dependent on the oxygen vacancy concentration and the B-site ions capacity for oxidation. The A-site ions simply serve to stabilize the lattice structure. Doping other ions at the A and B sites is beneficial to the generation of oxygen vacancies and the number of reactive oxygen species, which enhances the oxidation performance of the catalyst while still maintaining the original perovskite structure [73,74]. In La-Mn-based catalysts, when low-valence Sr2+ and K+ replace high-valence La3+, it will lead to charge imbalance and promote the formation of oxygen vacancies for charge compensation. After doping Cu at the B site, the generation of Mn4+ will be driven by the oxidation–reduction cycle of Cu2+ + Mn3+ ⇌ Mn4+ + Cu+, which plays a decisive role in the formation of oxygen vacancies, accelerates the generation and migration of active oxygen, and improves the activity of the catalyst. During the soot catalytic oxidation reaction, O2 is adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface and then activated to form O*. Active oxygen can directly oxidize soot to generate carbon-oxygen intermediates (CO*), which then react with gas-phase O2 to generate CO2. It can be seen from reaction formula 5 that O2 can obtain electrons from Cu+, and generate chemically adsorbed oxygen again (O2→O2−→O*), and at the same time, Cu+ becomes Cu2+ again, forming a continuous redox cycle. In addition, the presence of NO will accelerate the catalysis of soot [75]. This is because NO will react with active oxygen in the catalyst to generate NO2, which has strong oxidizing properties and can oxidize soot into CO2. (1) C u 2 + + M n 3 + → C u + + M n 4 + (2) M n 4 + + O 2 − l a t t → M n 3 + + O * + O v a c (3) O * + C → C O * (4) C O * + O 2 → C O 2 (5) C u + + O 2 ( g a s ) + O v a c → C u 2 + + O 2 − l a t t (6) N O + O * → N O * 2 → N O 2 (7) 2 N O 2 + C → C O 2 + 2 N O 4 Conclusions A series of LM-based perovskite catalysts modified at the A and B sites were prepared by the citric acid sol-gel method. The PDOS of LM before and after A and B site modifications was calculated based on DFT. With the use of various characterization methods and TPO activity assessment studies, the impact of doping on the physical and chemical characteristics of LM-based perovskite was investigated. According to the findings of the XRD, FT-IR, and TEM analyses, the produced catalysts maintain their perovskite structure and do not include any other crystal structures. This shows that the doping of perovskite A and B sites will not destroy the original structure of perovskite, and the doped ions (Sr2+, K+ and Cu2+) can enter the perovskite catalyst very well. The catalyst itself contains a variety of oxygen species, including lattice oxygen, strongly chemisorbed oxygen, and chemisorbed oxygen. At lower temperatures, chemisorbed oxygen performs an oxidation function (like soot oxide). The amount of chemisorbed oxygen and high-valence active ions (Mn4+) rises due to the doping of Sr, K, and Cu. The maximum amount of chemisorbed oxygen and high-valence active ions is found in LSK0.12MCu0.1 among all catalysts. According to the DFT calculation findings, the interaction between O and Mn in the valence band of 0 eV 10 eV in PDOS is larger than that between O and La. The doping of Sr and K on the A site of LM perovskite leads to the emergence of many unsaturated coordination bonds, promotes the production of high-valence active material (Mn4+), and produces more crystal oxygen defects on the surface of the catalyst, thus increasing the content of active oxygen. This is due to the existence of crystal cell oxygen defects that absorb oxygen and produce reactive oxygen species. With the addition of the transition metals Cu, Co and Ni to the B site, the activity of the catalyst was further enhanced. In particular, the LSK0.12MCuy catalyst doped with Cu can effectively promote the combustion of soot. The one with the greatest catalytic activity is LSK0.12MCu0.1, and the T90 under loose contact with NO reaches 399 and 420 °C, respectively. This is because the doped Cu2+ has grown to be a significant component of the system, taking up some of the Mn site in the B site to form the Cu–O–Mn bond and the Mn(Cu)O6 octahedral structure, which improves the stability of the catalyst structure and encourages the creation of oxygen vacancies and the release of active oxygen. The existence of Sr2+ and K+ increases the number of unsaturated coordination ions in the system, which makes it easy to form more oxygen defect unit cells, and the formation of more oxygen vacancies is committed to adsorbing more oxygen to increase the content of active oxygen species in the catalyst system. This study provides an important theoretical reference for the design of low-cost and high-performance soot catalysts. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a series of LaMnO3 (LM) perovskite catalysts modified at A and B sites were prepared to accelerate soot combustion. The La0.68Sr0.2K0.12Mn0.9Cu0.1O3-δ (LSK0.12MCu0.1) modified by Sr, K and Cu has good catalytic activity and cycle stability, the presence of NO can obviously promote the oxidation of soot. A variety of characterization results show that doping the A and B sites of perovskite will not destroy the original structure of perovskite, and the doped ions (Sr2+, K+, and Cu2+) can enter the perovskite catalyst well, which may be conducive to the formation of more oxygen defects and active oxygen species. According to the DFT calculation, adding Sr and K to the A sites can alter how atoms interact in a perovskite catalyst, increase the amount of unsaturated coordination bonds, and encourage the development of high-valence active ions (Mn4+) and oxygen defects. The doping of transition metal to the B sites results in the formation of the Cu-O-Mn link, which forms the Mn(Cu)O6 octahedron and stimulates the development of oxygen vacancies and the release of active oxygen. This study will provide an important reference for developing non-precious metal-based perovskite materials with high activity and low cost for catalytic combustion.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental and theoretical investigation on the high activity La0.8-xSr0.2KxMn1-yByO3-δ perovskite catalyst with combined A and B site modifications
